seo.title: How to download - Open Panda
seo.description: Learn how to download files from a decentralized storage network using Open Panda. We're currently in a state of rapid iteration to further improve the download experience.

col_2.heading: How to download data from Open Panda
col_2.description: At this time, downloading from Open Panda does require some specialized command line tooling. However, we’re working on new features that will mitigate this need very soon. In the mean time, follow the steps below to download one or more CIDs from a dataset.

col_2.label: Select a Dataset
col_2.description: The first step is to find a dataset you’d like to download. Simply use the interface to filter through our available datasets and select one you’re interested in exploring further.

col_4.label: Choose a CID
col_4.description: Next, you’ll want to select one or multiple CIDs to download. Some datasets may be relatively small (under 32 GiB), so you’ll only see one CID to download. Larger datasets may comprise of many CIDs. Depending on your use case, you might need to download all of them, or only a few. Browse the CIDs or files within the dataset and choose one to download.

col_6.label: Select a Storage Provider
col_6.description: Once you select a CID and click on it, you’ll notice it expands to show Storage Providers or SPs. Each SP may be located in a different geographic region, so it’s often a good idea to select one that’s physically close to you to reduce latency. SPs are identified by an ID that begins with the character f0... You may also want to pick a SP you’ve used before and have had a good experience with, based on their ID.

col_8.label: Copy a Command Line and run in Lotus
col_8.description:
Finally, upon selecting the SP of your choosing, you’ll see one or more retrieval commands appear in the interface. The most commonly used retrieval resource is a CLI tool called Lotus. Install Lotus on your computer and run the retrieval command when ready. For a tutorial on Lotus retrievals, see this documentation.

In the near future, you can expect additional features and tools which will simplify this process and make it more user friendly — thanks for being one of Open Panda’s early users!
